a_2.formal problem:
The problem you provided involves a specific numerical computation in a non-standard (base 5) numeral system. Isabelle does not support this numeral system directly, so the translation to Isabelle would involve creating a function to convert from base 5 to base 10, performing the division, and then converting back to base 5. This is beyond the scope of a simple theorem statement in Isabelle. However, here is a basic structure of how such a conversion function might look like:

```
fun base5_to_base10 :: "nat list -> nat"
where
"base5_to_base10 [] = 0"
| "base5_to_base10 (x#xs) = x * (5 ^ (length xs)) + base5_to_base10 xs"

fun base10_to_base5 :: "nat -> nat list"
where
"base10_to_base5 0 = []"
| "base10_to_base5 n = (n mod 5) # base10_to_base5 (n div 5)"

theorem
assumes h0 : "base5_to_base10 [1,1,2,1] div base5_to_base10 [1,2] = base5_to_base10 res"
shows  "res = [4,3]"
```
Note that this code will not work directly in Isabelle because it is not equipped to handle base 5 arithmetic out of the box. This is a simplification to illustrate the general idea.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "a = (\<lambda>n. if n = 0 then 1 else if n = 1 then 2 else if n = 2 then 1 else if n = 3 then 1 else 0)"
and h1 : "b = (\<lambda>n. if n = 0 then 2 else if n = 1 then 1 else 0)"
and h2 : "nat_of_nat_fun 5 a div nat_of_nat_fun 5 b = nat_of_nat_fun 5 (\<lambda>n. if n = 0 then 3 else if n = 1 then 4 else 0)"
shows  True
  using h0 h1 h2 by presburger
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Express the quotient $1121_5 \div 12_5$ in base $5$. The final Answer is 43_5. 
 ### Proof
 Long division in base $5$ follows the same format as that in base $10$. \[ \begin{array}{c|cccc} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & & 4 & 3 \\ \cline{2-5} 12 & 1 & 1 & 2 & 1 \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{1} & 0 & 3 & \downarrow \\ \cline{2-4}
 \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & & 4 & 1 \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & & 4 & 1 \\ \cline{4-5} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & & & 0 \end{array} \]Giving us a final answer of $\boxed{43_5. }$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "a = (\<lambda>n. if n = 0 then 1 else if n = 1 then 2 else if n = 2 then 1 else if n = 3 then 1 else 0)"
and h1 : "b = (\<lambda>n. if n = 0 then 2 else if n = 1 then 1 else 0)"
and h2 : "nat_of_nat_fun 5 a div nat_of_nat_fun 5 b = nat_of_nat_fun 5 (\<lambda>n. if n = 0 then 3 else if n = 1 then 4 else 0)"
shows  True
  using h0 h1 h2 by presburger
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem:
Define two functions $a$ and $b$ as follows:

$a(n) = 
\begin{cases} 
1 & \text{if } n = 0 \\
2 & \text{if } n = 1 \\
1 & \text{if } n = 2 \\
1 & \text{if } n = 3 \\
0 & \text{otherwise}
\end{cases}$

$b(n) = 
\begin{cases} 
2 & \text{if } n = 0 \\
1 & \text{if } n = 1 \\
0 & \text{otherwise}
\end{cases}$

It is given that the division of the natural number representation of function $a$ by the natural number representation of function $b$ over the first 5 indices equals the natural number representation of a function which equals 3 at index 0, 4 at index 1, and 0 otherwise. The statement is true.

 *)

assumes h0 : "x = nat_of_base 5 '1121'"
